children.value: We need two theorems and a lemma.
(Proof done in class, uses definition of congruence and Euclid’s lemma above)
We can see the pattern that , For every integers
, the modulo of it contains all then integers less then p
The difference of between them is a multiple of
will need to have a distinct congruence with respect to

\begin{aligned}
a \cdot 2a \cdot 3a \cdot ... \cdot (p-1)a &\equiv ( 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot ... \cdot p-1) a^{p-1} &\mod p \\
&\equiv ( 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot ... \cdot p-1) &\mod p \\
(p-1)!a^{p-1} &\equiv ( 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot ... \cdot p-1) &\mod p \\
&\equiv (p-1) &\mod p \\
p &\mid (p-1)! a^{p-1} - (p-1)! \\
p &\mid (p-1)! (a^{p-1} - 1) \\
p &\nmid (p-1)! \\
\therefore p &\mid a^{p-1} -1 \\
a^p &\equiv 1  &\mod p
\end{aligned}
